awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Requirement for N-Acetylglucosamine Transporters in Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Symbiosis
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Sarabeth Buckley is "Requirement for N-Acetylglucosamine Transporters in Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Symbiosis" The host institution for the fellowship is the Cambridge University, UK, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Uta Paszkowski.

This research studies how plants and mycorrhizae, a soil fungus, communicate to form a symbiosis. Mycorrhizae attach to roots of most plants and help them grow. The plant provides the mycorrhizae with carbohydrates and the mycorrhizae provides plant roots with nutrients. To start this relationship, the plants and mycorrhizae communicate by sending chemical signals to each other, which are not fully understood. This project studies a protein in plants that is likely the first protein a plant needs to start communication. If the puzzle pieces of the entire process of communication can be identified and put together, that knowledge could be used to make plants grow better by enhancing this connection or introducing pieces of it to other plants. Increasing plant growth sustainably could help agricultural systems work with nature to grow more food and use carbon from the atmosphere. This training will provide critical skills as the fellow transitions from studying environmental science to plant molecular biology. Results from this research will be shared with the science community through conferences, but also the local community through programs such as those that increase opportunities for young women in science.

The protein of interest, NOPE1, is a N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) transporter in plant roots. In mycorrhizae there is a homologous protein, NGT1. In the absence of NOPE1 a symbiosis between mycorrhizal fungus and roots cannot be established. This study answers 1. Are NOPE1 and NGT1 both essential for establishing a symbiosis and where are they expressed? 2. What is the signaling molecule transported by both? 3. How are molecules transported? It is hypothesized that: 1. Both NOPE1 and NGT1 are essential and are expressed close to where colonization occurs. 2. The molecules transported by NOPE1 and NGT1 are from both plants and fungi and are similar to N-acetylglucosamine. 3. NOPE1 and NGT1 transport these molecules both in and out of plant and fungus. Through this study the fellow will learn and use gene silencing, in situ hybridization, fluorescent tagging, and multiphoton confocal microscopy to observe gene expression. Relevant genes will be transferred to xenopus oocyte and to apply electro-physiological techniques in the presence of candidate molecules. Unknown molecules will be identified using LC-MS and NMR. RNAseq transcriptome analysis will provide insight into dynamics of downstream effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most land plants can form a beneficial relationship with a fungus called mycorrhizae, which grows into and/or around the roots of the plants. Tree-like structures called arbuscules form inside the roots and exchange nutrients between the two. The plant gives the fungus sugar from photosynthesis in exchange for nutrients and water. This can significantly improve plant growth and nutrition. Initiating this relationship requires careful coordination through sending chemical signals back and forth between the fungus and plant. Proteins move these chemicals in and out of the plant and fungus. One of the first proteins in the plant activated during this communication is called NOPE1. It can transport a molecule called N-acetyl glucosamine or GlcNAc, which makes up the wall of the fungus. When the plant is mutated to not be able to produce this protein, the fungus grows to the plant, but it is not able to enter the roots, which prevents the positive relationship from forming. This was shown by a previous study. Very rarely, the fungus could enter the root and then it was believed it could grow normally.

The current project expands our knowledge of the role this protein plays in the rest of the relationship between the plant and fungus. On top of needing this protein to enter the root, NOPE1 has now been found to be important throughout the plant and fungus’s relationship. It was possible that it would just take longer for the relationship to develop since some of the fungus can get into the plant and that eventually the same amount of fungus would be in both regular plants and plants without NOPE1. Looking at this relationship over time for the first time showed that the plants that do not produce NOPE1 do develop this relationship, but at a much lower level throughout the course of the plants life. Even after months and beginning to flower, the plants without this protein have much less of the positive fungus in their roots. The lack of this relationship stunts their growth. This is supported by the fact that in plants where this protein was made to glow, the protein was found throughout the inside of the plant roots and appears to be involved in the fungus traveling through to new areas. It also was found next to the tree-like arbuscules as well, so it could play a role during the stage when nutrients are being exchanged. A consistent new finding related to this was that, in the plants which did not make NOPE1, the arbuscules that did form were overall much smaller and in a collapsing form. Overall, the biggest finding is that NOPE1 is not only important in the initial stages where the fungus enters the plant, but throughout the majority of the relationship.

It is important to understand all the steps involved in such an important relationship. Once we know about all of it, this can provide an opening for further enhancing this beneficial relationship to further enhance plant growth. It could also be used in engineering projects trying to mimic this kind of relationship. If we are able to further enhance crop growth, this would impact the overall yield from agriculture, which would provide more resources in the form of food. If this can produce more food while producing less carbon, this could help address climate change, which would preserve many of the resources humans currently have that are at risk. Increasing the amount of food will also be necessary as our population continues to increase. It will make individual areas of land more productive, so we can preserve other areas of land that are able to store larger quantities of carbon. As it is, more productive agricultural land would draw down more CO2.

To try to communicate about this relationship to the public, our lab continued to attend public science fairs where we set up tables where people could look at the fungus under a microscope and learn about mycorrhizae through games.
